security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and guidance skill for AI tool design. Contains markdown documentation and a Python utility script for generating tool descriptions. No network calls, file system access beyond its own files, environment variable reading, or external command execution. Pure informational content with no execution capabilities that could harm users.

content.value_statement: Poorly designed tools create failure modes that no amount of prompt engineering can fix. This skill provides proven principles for creating tool descriptions, naming conventions, error handling, and architectural patterns that help agents succeed.
actual_capabilities: Apply the consolidation principle to reduce tool count and ambiguity
Write tool descriptions that answer what, when, and what returns
Design error messages that enable agent recovery
Implement response format options for token efficiency
Apply architectural reduction patterns from production systems
Use MCP fully qualified tool names to avoid tool not found errors
limitations: Does not execute code or modify external systems
Does not integrate with specific frameworks or platforms
Does not validate or test tool implementations
Provides guidance only; requires user implementation

use_cases.title: Design New Agent Tools
use_cases.description: Create effective tool descriptions and schemas following proven principles for agent comprehension.

use_cases.title: Consolidate Tool Collections
use_cases.description: Reduce tool complexity using the consolidation principle and architectural reduction patterns.

use_cases.title: Optimize Existing Tools
use_cases.description: Diagnose tool-related failures and improve descriptions for better agent performance.

prompt_templates.title: Create New Tool
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a tool for [use case]. Include: name using verb-noun pattern, description answering what it does and when to use it, parameters with types and constraints, return format, and error cases with recovery guidance.

prompt_templates.title: Evaluate Description
prompt_templates.prompt: Evaluate this tool description for clarity, completeness, and actionability. Identify vague language, missing sections, and ambiguous parameter names. Suggest improvements.

prompt_templates.title: Apply Reduction
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this tool collection of [number] tools. Identify consolidation opportunities using the architectural reduction principle. Recommend how to reduce to fewer comprehensive tools while maintaining capability.

prompt_templates.title: Optimize Tool
prompt_templates.prompt: Given this tool specification and observed failure modes: [describe failures]. Analyze why agents fail and propose improved descriptions that address these issues.

output_examples.input: Design a tool for querying customer information
output: get_customer - Retrieve customer information by ID or email
When: User asks about specific customer details, history, or status
Parameters: customer_id (string, required, format: CUST-######), email (string, optional), format (string, optional: concise|detailed)
Returns: Customer object with id, name, email, account_status, order_history

best_practices: Write descriptions that clearly answer what the tool does, when to use it, and what it returns
Apply the consolidation principle: if a human cannot determine which tool to use, an agent cannot either
Design error messages with agent recovery as the primary consideration, including resolution guidance
anti_patterns: Using vague descriptions like "Search the database" without specific context or parameter details
Using cryptic parameter names like x, val, or param1 that force agents to guess meaning
Inconsistent naming across tools (id in some, identifier in others, customer_id in some) creates confusion

faq.question: Which AI platforms support these tool design patterns?
faq.answer: The principles apply to all major agent platforms including Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. The MCP naming convention is specific to Model Context Protocol implementations.

faq.question: What is the recommended number of tools for an agent?
faq.answer: Research suggests 10-20 tools for most applications. Use namespacing to organize larger collections. Consolidate overlapping tools to reduce ambiguity.

faq.question: How does tool design connect to context management?
faq.answer: Tool descriptions are loaded into agent context and collectively shape behavior. Better descriptions reduce context usage while improving agent decisions.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using these patterns?
faq.answer: This skill provides design guidance only. It does not access, read, or modify your data. Implementation decisions about sandboxing and access control remain with the developer.

faq.question: Why do agents fail with well-designed tools?
faq.answer: Common causes include model capability limitations, unclear user intent, missing context, or tool purpose mismatches. Use observed failure modes to iteratively improve descriptions.

faq.question: How is architectural reduction different from tool consolidation?
faq.answer: Consolidation combines related tools into comprehensive tools. Reduction goes further by replacing specialized tools with primitive capabilities like file system access. Reduction works when documentation quality is high and model capability is sufficient.
